chapter.title: Tables
chapter.para: In this chapter we give tables referred to from the field descriptions in some chapters.

para.emphasis: Equivalent Day Count Fraction in ISDA 2006 Definitions

entry.para: Number of days in the interest period on the basis of a year of 360 days with 12 30-day months, divided by 360. For instance, if the interest period is from 5/18 to 8/18, the number of days in the interest period is 3x30=90.

Note: If the end of the interest period is the 31st of a month, but the beginning is a day other than the 30th or 31st of the month, then the last month will not be considered to be shortened to a 30-day month. Where the period length is one month and three days, the one month is assumed to have 30 days (irrespective of whether it has more), plus the three days resulting in a period of 33 days.
Number of days calculated on the basis of 12 thirty-day months over 360 days. The 31st day of a month is skipped.
Number of days in an interest period is calculated based on a 365-day year with 12 30-day months. This is similar to the 30/360 basis except the annual day count is 365 instead of 360.

30/Actual. Number of days in an interest period is calculated based on the actual number of days in a year with 12 30-day months. If the interest period straddles a leap year, the portion in a non-leap year is based on a 365-day year and the portion in the leap year is based on a 366-day year. This is similar to the Actual basis except each month has 30 days.
Actual number of days in the interest period divided by 360.
Actual number of days in the interest period annualized over a 364-day year
Actual number of days in the interest period divided by 365.
Actual number of days between the start and end of the period—excluding February 29—over 365 days.
Act/365RR. This basis uses the same day count fraction as the A365F basis for a given period with denomination quantity and Act/365RR specific rounding applied during cash flow calculation.

Actual Russian. Actual number of days in the interest period is divided by actual number of days in a year. This is similar to the Actual basis that supports ISDA standard. The difference between ACTR and Actual is ACTR excludes the first day of the interest period and includes the last day while Actual behaves the opposite.

The interest amount calculated is similar for both bases, except when the interest period straddles a leap year. In this case, the number of days in each portion impacts the calculation because the non-leap portion is annualized over 365 days while the leap year portion is annualized over 366. The number of days for the ACTR basis in the first portion of the interest period is one day less than the Actual basis while the second portion has one day more.

Actual number of days in the interest period, divided by actual number of days in a year. If the interest period straddles a leap year, the portion of the interest in non-leap-years is divided by 365 and the portion in the leap year by 366.
A variant on the Actual method, where 366 is only used if February 29 actually falls within the interest period.
Actual/182-183. Number of days in an interest period is calculated based on a 365-day year where the first and every odd period has 182 days while every even period has 183 days.
Actual number of business days between start and end of the period over 252 days.

Actual number of days between the start and end of the period, divided by 365, if the period does not start in a leap year. If the period does start in a leap year, the number of days is divided by 366.
Actual number of days between the start and end of the period, divided by 365, if the period does not end in a leap year. If it does end in a leap year, the number of days is divided by 366.

The interest rate refers to the annual amount (i.e., rate is divided by the number of payments within a year) and the day count is the actual number of days in the interest period divided by the number of days in a year for the payment period. For example, a 1,000,000 swap on Coupon basis was reset to 8%. Interest is paid semi-annually. Cash flow from 30/08/2007 to 28/02/2008 will be calculated as follows:
2 is the number of interest payments within a year
182 is the actual number of days from 30/08/2007 to 28/02/2008
184 is the number of days for the half year period
Discounted, based on actual number of days in the interest period divided by 360. For a principal of P, a discount rate of R, and a period of d days, the interest calculation is:
Actual number of days between the start and end of the period over 360 days.
Discounted, based on actual number of days in the interest period divided by 365. For a principal of P, a discount rate of R, and a period of d days, the interest calculation is:
Actual number of days between the start and end of the period over 365 days.

The notional is expressed in units per day, used for commodities. This is a modified version of the Price method. When this option is used, the price for the day is multiplied by the notional every day of the period then the daily amounts are netted.

For example, an oil swap would usually pay on a daily basis as follows: if the period is 3 days long, the notional is 1,000 bbl and the prices are 20 on the first day, 21 on the second and 22 on the third day. Then, the payment at the end of the three days will be:

This calculation implements the German DRV basis. It differs from the Eurobond basis above in just one respect: if the termination date of the final period is the last day of February, then February is considered to be 30 days long.

The calculation for this basis is similar to that for 30/360E, with one notable difference. For the Eurobond basis, all months are considered to be 30 days long, irrespective of their actual calendar length. However, if the termination date of the final period is the last day of February, the actual number of days in the month (28 or 29) is used instead for this period.
Similar to the Coupon method. However, the first and last coupon may NOT be equal because of stub periods. All coupons (full and partial) are rounded down to 7 decimal places.

Used for equity swaps, the payment is calculated as change in price times the notional. For example, if the notional of the leg is 10,000 shares (units) of IBM, it resets monthly. If the share price at the beginning of the period was 135 and the ending price is 140, the payment is calculated as:
Payment is calculated as price * notional.
Note: For resets in advance, the price represents the start of the period; for resets in arrears, it represents the end of the period.

The forward rates applied during the stub period will be generated by adding the Term specified on the trade window to the start date of the forward application period to derive the end date. Please note that this selection may produce gaps or overlaps in the forward application periods.

The forward rates applied during the stub period will be generated from date to date (e.g., from the start date of the stub application period to the end date of the application period, calculating the exact number of days)
Stub payment will be computed based on the effective rate between the start and payment days.
The rate is decompounded based on the payment frequency. Currently, only decompounding from the daily compounded annual rate (Brazil market convention) is supported.
If the stub rate is defined, it is simply used as defined.
If the stub rate is not defined, the asset rate is used regardless of the asset decompounding setting
Rates are decompounded according to the following formula:
D : number of interest days in the rate coverage period
n : number of payment periods in year (pay frequency)
If the stub rate is defined, decompounding is based on the stub rate and on the number of days in the stub period.
If the stub rate is not defined, decompounding is based on the asset rate and on the number of days in the stub period.

The fixed (compounded) rate is converted to a simple rate for each payment period. The number of interest days in the payment periods is calculated according to the asset day count basis. The asset stubs are separate payment periods.
Rates are decompounded according to the following formula:
D : number of interest days in the rate coverage period
n : number of payment periods in year (pay frequency)
The rate is decompounded based on the payment frequency. Currently, only decompounding from the daily compounded annual rate (Brazil market convention) is supported.

row.entry: Adjusts the schedule to the next business day. For example, if 1/10 is a Sunday; roll forward to 1/11 which is a Monday.
Adjusts the schedule to the preceding business day. For example, if 1/10 is a Sunday; roll backward to 1/8 which is a Friday.

Adjusts the schedule to the next business day unless that date falls in the following month, in which case adjust to the preceding business day. For example, if 1/10 is a Sunday; roll forward to 1/11 which is a Monday; unless 1/31 is a Sunday, then roll back to 1/29, which is a Friday.

entry.para: Adjusts the schedule to the preceding business day unless that day falls in the prior month, in which case adjust to the next business day. For example, if 1/10 is a Saturday; roll back to 1/9 which is a Friday; unless 2/1 is a Saturday then roll forward to 2/3 which is a Monday.

row.entry: Is identical to the Modified Following method except that it sets the roll date to be the new day. For example, if a schedule is set to roll quarterly on the 15th of every month, the schedule will go from the 15th of one month to the 15th of the subsequent month. If the 15th of the subsequent month is a non-business day, that date will be rolled forward (Modified Following) to the 16th. The schedule will then continue going to the 16th of the subsequent month, and so on. Eventually, the anniversary will march forward to the end of the month, at which point it will keep an anniversary of 31 (end of month.)

Supports South African Bonds that use the SAJSE price/yield method. For schedule generation, 2/28 is recognized as the end of the month even during leap year, 2/29. For accrual calculations, leap year, 2/29 is recognized.

entry.para: Select this option to view the Premium settle %of the Notional Amount in the Main Currency. For example, where the Currency pair is USD/JPY, the Premium settle % appears as USD currency. The premium cash calculation is: Premium Cash = Notional in Main Currency * Premium %.
If you change the Premium Ccy field from the Main Currency (USD) to the Money Currency (JPY), the quotation mode automatically defaults to %Money.

Select this option to view the Premium settle % of the Notional Amount in the Money Currency. For example, where the Currency pair is USD/JPY, the Premium settle % appears as JPY currency. The premium cash calculation is: Premium Cash = Notional in Money Currency * Premium %.
If you change the Premium Amount currency field from the Money Currency (JPY) to the Main Currency (USD), the quotation mode automatically defaults to %Main.

Select this option to view the Premium settle %of the Notional Amount in the Main currency. Here the Premium settle % appears as USD currency. The premium cash calculation is: Premium Cash = Notional in Money Currency * Premium %.
If you change the Premium Ccy field from the Main Currency (USD) to the Money Currency (JPY), the quotation mode automatically defaults to Money/%Main.

Select this option to view the Premium settle %of the Notional Amount in the Money Currency. Here the Premium settle % appears as JPY currency. The premium cash calculation is: Premium Cash = Notional in Main Currency * Premium %
If you change the Premium Ccy field from the Money Currency (JPY) to the Main Currency (USD), the quotation mode automatically defaults to Main/%Money.
